text: Karst-de-Saint-Elzéar Biodiversity Reserve () is a biodiversity reserve located in Gaspésie–Îles-de-la-Madeleine, Quebec, Canada, around north of the town of Saint-Elzéar. It was established on June 20, 2005. It lies between latitudes 48°13’N and 48°19’N and between longitudes 65°17’W and 65°25’W. The elevation of the reserve lies at between and . Within the reserve, seven caves have been discovered, although only one of them (grotte de Saint-Elzéar) is open to the public. It is the only reserve to conserve a karst. The cave is always , whatever the time of year. It is long and deep. It is estimated to be around 230,000 years old, making it one of the oldest caves in Quebec. ==References== Category:IUCN Category III Category:Protected areas established in 2005 Category:Protected areas of Gaspésie–Îles-de-la-Madeleine
title: Karst-de-Saint-Elzéar Biodiversity Reserve
